content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is how you can do this in Julia using DataFrames package:

```julia
using DataFrames, Pkg
Pkg.activate("..")  # activate environment for installing packages
Pkg.add("DataFrames")
using CSV
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter data to include only "audi" manufacturer and model in ["a4", "a4 quattro"]
    df = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi" && (row[:model] == "a4" || row[:model] == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Add a new column called `audi_a4_type` with value `true` across all rows
    df[:audi_a4_type] = true

    return df
end
```
Please note that you need to have the DataFrames package installed in your Julia environment. If it's not installed yet, use the Pkg.add("DataFrames") line of code to install it. 

Remember also to activate the environment using Pkg.activate("..") before installing and adding packages.
